text: @W_R_Chase @axios @caitlinnowens Appreciate all of the effort data journalists are putting into unpacking the polarization of the pandemic through data. @JossFong's video does a great job pulling pieces of that story together too  https://t.co/h2noKE7YgY

My colleagues hosted a virtual farewell for me today. On the menti was an ask for 'one thing you've learned from Amanda.'

In the midst of various things about #dataviz, design, client management, and meeting facilitation was: 

"All varieties of N95 masks."

Ah, pandemic times.

"In the United States, it's estimated that for every four deaths due to COVID-19, one child loses a parent or caregiver."

Our American resistance to doing small things (like wearing masks) to save children this pain is absurd.

https://t.co/JyzwWp7riG

In the pandemic, one of the rare points of divergence from the norm of American individualism and rationing on ability to pay was free testing, treatment, and vaccination services. 

"Remember the melon lady..." https://t.co/CyU5wt9cjJ https://t.co/TTP5vWhYyl

@bethlinas @katieporteroc @JossFong Her pandemic polarization video is exceptional, and I think one of the big draws in it is the approach using transparencies, writing/drawing in components of the charts, and seeing her hands working with the data. https://t.co/l2CMbWXy5O

The continued drumbeat from practitioners-turned-pundits that the vaccinated can 'return to normal' disregards the impact of community spread and concerns about #longcovid in ways that are counter to the core mission I was taught in public health school.

#UrgencyofEquity https://t.co/ZhGqN6MXOF

@AlexKale17 @POTUS Same in my public health circles - and it just pisses me off that as we make this an 'individual choice' issue the politicians and political appointees aren't making those choices any easier by branding masks as a 'scarlet letter of the pandemic' or limiting access to data.

Reading the full memo is just disheartening. We could be saying 'lets use appropriate on/off ramps' for masks and such, but instead @POTUS is taking the politically advantageous route of declaring victory over the pandemic.

Full text: https://t.co/VxaogeoiJe

@biosplonk I feel like the narrow focus on the epi part of public health made sense in the early days of the pandemic, but SBCC, health comms, and related specialties should have had the spotlight for much of the last two years --- and instead the mic got passed to MDs.

Today & tomorrow I'm in a #VIZBI2022 expert workshop on COVID-19 #dataviz and communication, which kicked off with lightning talks from each participant.

One of the stickiest images I've seen so far was an iceberg metaphor around the daunting challenge of #longcovid. https://t.co/Abtpoo058x

@PaulSaxMD #dataviz has been a critical tool for communicating information about COVID but also a tool to amplify misinformation (purposefully) and often misunderstood or misrepresented because of the complexity and uncertainty of the data.
It seems the 'pandemic is over' talking points have really stuck. https://t.co/tZldzcV24G

It's such cognitive dissonance to see a green map as my timeline is full of #longcovid, US increases in COVID detection in wastewater surveillance, and data from Europe clearly showing another wave as NPIs get dropped. https://t.co/MPJYYkX4mH

I love seeing this kind of messaging coming from the @WHCOVIDResponse.

I wish the @CDCgov would be equally enthusiastic as they set thresholds and recommendations for NPIs like masks, and promote more preparedness through systems changes, like ventilation. https://t.co/wveOOeGAOn
